title: Cracking the code: How to wow the acceptance committee at your next tech event
description: Want to speak at a tech conference? These four practical tips will help your session proposal stand out‚Äîand land you on the stage. The post Cracking the code: How to wow the acceptance committee at your next tech event appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
author: Rachel Cohen
excerpt: Want to speak at a tech conference? These four practical tips will help your session proposal stand out‚Äîand land you on the stage.
text: GitHub Universe returns to San Francisco on October 28 and 29‚Äîbringing together the builders, dreamers, and changemakers shaping the future of software. From first-time speakers with big ideas to DevRel pros with demos to share and business leaders rethinking workflows with AI, we believe that a diverse range of voices belong on our stage. But writing a compelling conference session submission can feel like decoding a complex algorithm. What makes your idea stand out? How do you grab the content committee‚Äôs attention? And what if you‚Äôve never done this before? Good news: we‚Äôve cracked the code, and we‚Äôre sharing it with you. Here are four proven tips to help you put together a proposal that‚Äôs clear, compelling, and uniquely you. Apply to speak or nominate a speaker to take the stage at GitHub Universe by Friday, May 2 at 11:59 pm PT to be considered. 1. Find something you‚Äôre truly passionate about üí° Here‚Äôs the truth: passion is magnetic. If you‚Äôre excited about your topic, it shows. It pulses through your proposal, powers your delivery onstage, and pulls in your audience‚Äîcontent committee included. Instead of chasing the latest trends, talk about something that lights you up. Maybe it‚Äôs a story from building an open source project in your off-hours. Maybe it‚Äôs how your team shipped something new using GitHub Copilot. Or maybe it‚Äôs the unexpected way you quickly scaled developer experience across a global org. Your unique perspective is your superpower. Content committees can sense authenticity. They‚Äôre not just looking for polished buzzwords. They‚Äôre looking for people who care deeply and can teach others something meaningful. üé§ Pro tip: If it‚Äôs a topic you‚Äôd talk about over lunch with a teammate or geek out about on a podcast, it‚Äôs probably a great fit. 2. Write a title they can‚Äôt ignore ‚úçÔ∏è Think of your session title like an email subject line‚Äîit‚Äôs your chance to make a strong first impression, and it needs to do the heavy lifting for you. A strong title shouldn‚Äôt just sound good. It should clearly communicate what your talk is about and why it matters. Let‚Äôs take our title as an example: ‚úÖ Engaging: ‚ÄúCracking the Code‚Äù suggests there‚Äôs an inside strategy, and it sparks curiosity. ‚úÖ Clear: ‚ÄúHow to wow the acceptance committee at your next tech event‚Äù leaves no doubt about the topic. ‚úÖ Action-oriented: It promises practical takeaways, not just theory. ‚úÖ Balanced: It walks the line between fun and professional. Avoid vague titles (‚ÄúA new approach to software‚Äù) or clickbait (‚ÄúThis one trick will fix your codebase‚Äù). Instead, aim for clarity with flair. Give the content committee a reason to want to learn more along with the confidence that your talk can deliver. üé§ Pro tip: After you write your title, ask yourself‚Äîwould I attend this session? Would I understand what I‚Äôm getting from it in five seconds? 3. Make it easy for the content committee to say yes ‚úÖ The content committee is rooting for you, but you‚Äôve got to help them out. The best submissions remove all ambiguity and make a strong case for why this session matters. Here‚Äôs how: Be specific about your audience: Who is this for? Senior engineers? OSS maintainers? Platform teams? Product leads? Spell out the takeaways: What will people learn? Tools, frameworks, fresh mindsets? Tie it to the event: Why does this belong at GitHub Universe? How does it support the event‚Äôs themes? Also, show that your content has a life beyond the stage: Can your session be turned into a blog, case study, or video? Is your abstract compelling enough to be featured in a marketing email or keynote recap? Will attendees be able to apply what they learned the next day? üé§ Hot tip: Think beyond the talk itself. That‚Äôs pure gold for event organizers. 4. Seal the deal with your online presence üåê Yes, your session submission is the star, but reviewers on the content committee can also look you up. Your online presence helps us understand: Your credibility and expertise Your speaking experience (or potential!) How easy it will be to promote you as a speaker You don‚Äôt need a massive following. But you do want a strong, relevant footprint. Here are a few tips to consider: On LinkedIn: Optimize headline and bio Share speaking experience Engage with your network Use a headline that highlights your expertise, not just your title. Make your ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù section shine with links to talks, blogs, and projects. Add speaking experience under ‚ÄúExperience‚Äù or ‚ÄúFeatured.‚Äù On GitHub: Update your profile README Have public contributions Showcase recent activity Update your profile README with your focus areas and links. Pin key repos or projects you‚Äôve contributed to. Be active in discussions, even if most of your code is private. üé§ Hot tip: Post about your submission journey! Sharing your process helps you engage with the community and might even inspire someone else to apply. Ready to take the stage? You‚Äôve got the ideas. Now you‚Äôve got the blueprint. If you‚Äôve made it this far, we hope you feel ready‚Äîand excited‚Äîto throw your hat in the ring. Let‚Äôs recap: Lead with passion to find a topic you care deeply about. Craft a clear, compelling title that grabs attention and gives the content committee an immediate idea of your session topic and takeaways. Make your submission a no-brainer by showing how it aligns with the event and adds value. Polish your online presence‚Äîit might just tip the scale in your favor. Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned speaker or stepping into the spotlight for the first time, we can‚Äôt wait to hear from you. And if you don‚Äôt have a session idea this year, you can also nominate a speaker who deserves to take the stage. Submit a session proposal or a speaker nomination from now until Friday, May 2 at 11:59 pm PT to be considered! Let‚Äôs build the future together‚Äîone session at a time. üí´ Related posts Explore more from GitHub Docs Everything you need to master GitHub, all in one place. html:
GitHub Universe returns to San Francisco on October 28 and 29‚Äîbringing together the builders, dreamers, and changemakers shaping the future of software. From first-time speakers with big ideas to DevRel pros with demos to share and business leaders rethinking workflows with AI, we believe that a diverse range of voices belong on our stage.

But writing a compelling conference session submission can feel like decoding a complex algorithm. What makes your idea stand out? How do you grab the content committee‚Äôs attention? And what if you‚Äôve never done this before?

Good news: we‚Äôve cracked the code, and we‚Äôre sharing it with you.

Here are four proven tips to help you put together a proposal that‚Äôs clear, compelling, and uniquely you.

Apply to speak or nominate a speaker to take the stage at GitHub Universe by Friday, May 2 at 11:59 pm PT to be considered.

1. Find something you‚Äôre truly passionate about üí°

Here‚Äôs the truth: passion is magnetic. If you‚Äôre excited about your topic, it shows. It pulses through your proposal, powers your delivery onstage, and pulls in your audience‚Äîcontent committee included.

Instead of chasing the latest trends, talk about something that lights you up. Maybe it‚Äôs a story from building an open source project in your off-hours. Maybe it‚Äôs how your team shipped something new using GitHub Copilot. Or maybe it‚Äôs the unexpected way you quickly scaled developer experience across a global org. Your unique perspective is your superpower.

Content committees can sense authenticity. They‚Äôre not just looking for polished buzzwords. They‚Äôre looking for people who care deeply and can teach others something meaningful.

üé§ Pro tip: If it‚Äôs a topic you‚Äôd talk about over lunch with a teammate or geek out about on a podcast, it‚Äôs probably a great fit.

2. Write a title they can‚Äôt ignore ‚úçÔ∏è

Think of your session title like an email subject line‚Äîit‚Äôs your chance to make a strong first impression, and it needs to do the heavy lifting for you. A strong title shouldn‚Äôt just sound good. It should clearly communicate what your talk is about and why it matters.

Let‚Äôs take our title as an example:

  • ‚úÖ Engaging: ‚ÄúCracking the Code‚Äù suggests there‚Äôs an inside strategy, and it sparks curiosity.

  • ‚úÖ Clear: ‚ÄúHow to wow the acceptance committee at your next tech event‚Äù leaves no doubt about the topic.

  • ‚úÖ Action-oriented: It promises practical takeaways, not just theory.

  • ‚úÖ Balanced: It walks the line between fun and professional.

Avoid vague titles (‚ÄúA new approach to software‚Äù) or clickbait (‚ÄúThis one trick will fix your codebase‚Äù). Instead, aim for clarity with flair. Give the content committee a reason to want to learn more along with the confidence that your talk can deliver.

üé§ Pro tip: After you write your title, ask yourself‚Äîwould I attend this session? Would I understand what I‚Äôm getting from it in five seconds?

3. Make it easy for the content committee to say yes ‚úÖ

The content committee is rooting for you, but you‚Äôve got to help them out. The best submissions remove all ambiguity and make a strong case for why this session matters.

Here‚Äôs how:

  • Be specific about your audience: Who is this for? Senior engineers? OSS maintainers? Platform teams? Product leads?

  • Spell out the takeaways: What will people learn? Tools, frameworks, fresh mindsets?

  • Tie it to the event: Why does this belong at GitHub Universe? How does it support the event‚Äôs themes?

Also, show that your content has a life beyond the stage:

  • Can your session be turned into a blog, case study, or video?

  • Is your abstract compelling enough to be featured in a marketing email or keynote recap?

  • Will attendees be able to apply what they learned the next day?

üé§ Hot tip: Think beyond the talk itself. That‚Äôs pure gold for event organizers.

4. Seal the deal with your online presence üåê

Yes, your session submission is the star, but reviewers on the content committee can also look you up. Your online presence helps us understand:

  • Your credibility and expertise

  • Your speaking experience (or potential!)

  • How easy it will be to promote you as a speaker

You don‚Äôt need a massive following. But you do want a strong, relevant footprint. Here are a few tips to consider:

On LinkedIn:

  • Use a headline that highlights your expertise, not just your title.

  • Make your ‚ÄúAbout‚Äù section shine with links to talks, blogs, and projects.

  • Add speaking experience under ‚ÄúExperience‚Äù or ‚ÄúFeatured.‚Äù

On GitHub:

  • Update your profile README with your focus areas and links.

  • Pin key repos or projects you‚Äôve contributed to.

  • Be active in discussions, even if most of your code is private.

üé§ Hot tip: Post about your submission journey! Sharing your process helps you engage with the community and might even inspire someone else to apply.

Ready to take the stage?

You‚Äôve got the ideas. Now you‚Äôve got the blueprint. If you‚Äôve made it this far, we hope you feel ready‚Äîand excited‚Äîto throw your hat in the ring. Let‚Äôs recap:

  1. Lead with passion to find a topic you care deeply about.

  2. Craft a clear, compelling title that grabs attention and gives the content committee an immediate idea of your session topic and takeaways.

  3. Make your submission a no-brainer by showing how it aligns with the event and adds value.

  4. Polish your online presence‚Äîit might just tip the scale in your favor.

Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned speaker or stepping into the spotlight for the first time, we can‚Äôt wait to hear from you. And if you don‚Äôt have a session idea this year, you can also nominate a speaker who deserves to take the stage. Submit a session proposal or a speaker nomination from now until Friday, May 2 at 11:59 pm PT to be considered!

Let‚Äôs build the future together‚Äîone session at a time. üí´
